awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CICI: Secure and Resilient Architecture: S3D: A New SDN-Based Security Framework for the Science DMZ
awd_abstract_narration:
The Science DMZ (SDMZ) is a key foundational element in building state-of-the-art scientific research infrastructure. The SDMZ is a portion of the network, built at the campus or laboratory's edge, that is designed such that the equipment, configuration, and security policies are optimized for high-performance scientific applications rather than for general-purpose business systems or enterprise computing. SDMZs are increasingly being implemented by research agencies, campuses and national labs. In order to improve the throughput of scientific research data, NSF has funded many Science DMZ implementations on campuses by upgrading research network connectivity and encouraging installation of a SDMZ. However, the SDMZ has characteristics that separate it as a unique ecosystem which cannot simply adopt existing enterprise and cloud based network security technologies and policies. This project designs and prototypes an integrated Software Defined Network (SDN) security framework for managing data-intensive science applications utilizing the Science DMZ (SDMZ) model. It offers one of the first demonstrations of how fine-grained security controls can co-exist within a high performance data-intensive network. This project produces significant advancements in the trustworthiness and reliability of large-scale data-intensive scientific research infrastructures.

This project evaluates the current state of the SDMZ security architecture, then identifies the current shortcomings in its existing security services. The new proposed framework: 1) defines fine-grained network flow controls using dynamically deployable security services that are migratable and science-application aware; 2) defines a new class of network privilege management policies that can revoke or divert flows that violate SDMZ policies or that differ from user-defined, application-specific usage expectations; 3) establishes high-performance virtual circuits that enable data intensive applications to register and fast-path their authenticated flows across the SDMZ. Furthermore, this project introduces a unified security policy engine to dramatically simplify the control of the above three services. The policy engine offers a valuable and user-friendly abstraction to meet the domain-specific needs of the SDMZ.

por.por_cntn:
This project, Collaborative Research: CICI: Secure and Resilient Architecture: S3D: A New SDN-Based Security Framework for the Science DMZ, brought together three teams to design a comprehensive system for Science DMZ security based on software defined network (SDN) technology. SDN allows network programming and configuration like never before.

Indiana University worked on integrating our Flange, a flow-oriented network programming language , and our eXtensible Session Protocol (XSP) into the S3D model. Flange serves as a policy expression engine for forwarding policy in general, and for XSP in particular. We aimed to generalize it to support all legs of the proposed system.

Flange is a language designed to express policies about where network flows can go and how they should be handled. It is declarative in the sense that it has the user express desired outcomes, rather than exactly how to achieve them. The Science DMZ model attempts to improve network performance for scientific applications by careful managing firewalling, for instance. Flange allows us to express what should go through the firewall or other security apparatus as abstract data behavior, rather than concretely defined firewall or ACL policy.

XSP is a protocol that allows a user to establish a network session, which is a period of activity. The user authenticates for this session and tells a network controller what it intends to do. The network controller can consult the network policy in the Flange engine and make appropriate decisions. These can include things like routing around the firewall for performance improvement of known and identified network traffic, taking an alternate path with better performance, or prohibiting the request entirely.

Our work allowed us to express policies about flows and how they should be treated with regard to firewalling. This is far more flexible and expressive than the firewall systems and policies that were commonly used. It is also distinguished by expressing a desired goal, as opposed to a list of addresses and ports. Further, with the authentication capabilities provided by XSP, we are able to make security decisions based on who the user is, not just which computer they are using.

The intellectual merit of this project was in first in researching and demonstrating an active interface to the network security plane, allowing the software defined networking to treat specific application flows in a custom fashion. Second, we explored the use of our declarative language Flange to express security policy, allowing certain flows to take more efficient paths.  We built a working system and tested it and demonstrated it. Both of these capabilities have advanced the state of the are in Science DMZ security using SDN.

The broader impact of this work provides input for the capabilities of next-generation Science DMZs, improving their efficiency while also improving security. The Science DMZ model enables various scientific efforts by removing barriers to moving big data. Further, the ideas represented here are fundamental to network architectures and they have been presented in various university and community forums as examples of "smart networks" and many students were trained as part of this effort.
